description:
Located on Mission Street (a few blocks north of the 24th Street BART station), Grand Coffee is a small shop that offers your usual coffee/espresso based-drinks. They also offer non-coffee beverages if that's your jam, but my guess that if you are choosing to visit a place with "coffee" in the title, you are looking for a cup of Joe. 

I've tried their regular coffee and their Americano, and I thought both were well done. The Americano was smooth and not overly acidic, and the coffee was good even without cream and sugar. They offer Cuban pastries as well, and while I haven't tried them, I thought it was great that they offered something different than your usual cafe snacks. The service has been consistently friendly when I've visited, and there's a casual and welcoming vibe to the place that makes it very appealing. It's a small space, so I don't think it'd be great if you are looking for a place to work for long periods of time. However, you should definitely check it out if you're in the area!
author: Keith H.

description:
It's a cute spot here with cassette tapes of jazz mixes with Duke Ellington and Ella Fitzgerald amongst the madness of the Mission. Try it out cause the owners are cool people, I got a good vibe from them. Dude made my almond milk latte really well, and the milk was nice and frothy, so I'm happy. 

A little pricey but I'm happy to support this little place!
author: Caroline D.

description: Casual delicious neighborhood coffee place with limited seats and friendly staff. Espresso-based drinks are top notch.
author: Shaw L.

description: Super friendly, and serve delicious lattes! The art in the walls is cool in this tiny spot.
author: Roger P.

description: Cute little hole in the wall coffee house ! I ordered the ice latte and my boyfriend ordered an espresso shot on ice, both drinks were made right away and tasted great! I just wish they had more room for seating.
author: Saori S.

description:
Great coffee located in Mission.

Minus .5 star for not having a seat inside, minus another .5 for not serving non-fat milk. For some reason, I still dislike the strong flavor of almond/soy going with coffee...

A cute wall inside with all kinds of paper cup decorations.
author: Elaine H.

description: Hole in the wall place with reaaally good ice mochas. More of a grab and go place given that there isn't really any seating
author: Maggie S.

description: Best coffee place in town. Great customer service. Love the ice mochas here.  I asked the barista what's good here. He asked me what I liked. I love chocolate and he whipped me up the best chocolate ice mocha you could think of.
author: Abed H.

description:
Love the guava and cheese pastry! OMG! They also have some with chicken that are amazing too!
Drip coffee is quick. Free water (if you don't want to buy a bottle).
Great and honest customer service! (Don't be a tourist like me and ask if you can take a photo of the barista.
author: Jonna Leanne P.

description:
We stumbled upon this little shop while walking to Dolores Park. It smelled heavenly from outside, so we figured why not? A regular cup of coffee was $3. It was average by SF standards, but it was nice to have a $3 handwarmer as we headed out to the park. I think the coffee had been sitting out for a while, which probably affected the flavor. 

Tiny shop with no seating. Quick and friendly service. Coffee was just aight.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Best small coffee shop in the Mission.  I don't drink lattes so I can't really comment on the milk drinks but the Americano was perfect.

The best part is the staff; good, honest service without the pretense of the pour-over crowd.
author: Tom C.

description: Best neighborhood coffee! Wonderful staff and delicious beverages. Not much room to sit, more a grab and go place. My dog loves to vacuum up the pastry crumbs outside!
author: Aman H.

description: I didn't have a chance to even try the coffee when I was getting close to buy the guy from the store told me in the most bad possible way we are closed. I've been to places where they even had the decency to hear what I have to say but this guy didn't even care. If I could I would go -1 in customer service.
author: Victor V.

description:
The space of this coffee shop is incredibly small but it is good spot to grab a quick coffee and small snacks. 

I wouldn't mind coming back.
author: Dan Mark D.

description: Great little coffee spot. Never even noticed it before. Four Barrel made perfectly and with love.
author: Andrew K.

description: Great coffee. I'm a tea person and I can tell that this is not burnt, citrusy or bitter. A perfect cup made expediently and with care.
author: Isaak H.

description:
Small hole in the wall place to grab coffee and pastry in the Mission. It looked promising, but $3 for a cup of coffee that was watery, acidic and tasted like it had been sitting for hours was disappointing. Maybe their other latte / speciality drinks are better, but I've had better coffee from Starbucks, $1 coffee from McDonalds, or many other places.

No place to sit and chat, so if you're looking for a place to come do work, read, or come on a date / hang out with a friend, you'll be better off at Ritual just a block away on Valencia.
author: Christina L.

description:
I tried temporarily to stop my coffee habit since my office provides free four barrel, Philz, Starbucks, peets, and Sightglass coffee. The daily Philz addiction can definitely add up without you noticing. 

Today I returned to Grand Coffee for a regular cup of coffee but couldn't resist ordering a Cappuccino instead having seen another customer's luscious concoction. The espresso (Cappucino is $3.50, espresso is $2.50) was as smooth tasting as I remember and perfectly complemented with expertly foamed Califia Original Almond Milk (+0.50). I am so glad I ordered this because this was slightly sweet from the almond milk, rich and strong - I'm sending a new addiction. Suggested: Home-made pistachio milk in iced coffee for a pseudo affogato (+0.75). 

For order-in, enjoy your beverage at the small bar (4 stools) and a complementary seltzer palate cleanser. 

They also sell premium chocolate bars, my favorite brand of pastries (Knead pomme d'amores, pecan and plain croissants, lemon ricotta pop tarts, and chocolate chip cookies). On Mondays they only have pastries from Sandbox (chocolate croissant $3.50 - MEH).

Note: their prices have increased since last time I came. They have square - CC accepted. This is a super hipster place, I think the owner is nice and warms up to you especially the regulars, but can be a bit brusque at first. Say "hello" and he will be a lot nicer.
author: Jess C.

description: My cappuccino was bad: it was not had and it had no foam at all. It tasted like coffee you would get at a gas station. My partner had a soy capp which was just as bad+they charge extra for soy milk. Too bad, I Iive close by and heard good things about this place. Im lucky I still have Linea
author: Adelle G.

description: The barista was incredibly rude to my mother, and the coffee drinks were very bad. Everything tastes of burned coffee beans. No idea how this place is so highly rated. Go to ritual instead.
author: Alyssum G.

description:
This is a tiny coffee shop, with a tiny menu, but with awesome coffee. They just go to the point. 

The place has this kind of cool masculine vibe (simple decor, neutral colors, male waiters) and the people working there are very friendly and nice.

It was a hot day in SF when I came here, so I wanted something cold like a Frappucino. As I said, they have a small menu, so they didn't have it. But the guy helping me suggested this iced coffee latte drink (I'm not sure of the correct name). The dink was very good. Quite rich and creamy, but the coffee was definitely there and you could taste the quality.

There are almost no places to sit here, so don't plan on hanging around for too long. I would suggest just getting your drink and going somewhere else.

If you like coffee, you will like it here.
author: Andréia S.

description:
One of the COOLEST coffee shop in the City! Definitely a hole-in-the-wall because if you blink, you'd miss it! It's tiny but it delivers a mean, cappuccino!

Their flat white here is amazing. They serve Four Barrel Coffee which is fantastic. There are a couple of chairs outside for, but I much prefer their barstools inside. It's cozy!  Great for dates!

The decor here is funky. It makes me want to rip my jeans, show off a few holes, and possibly dye my hair purple, and put on yellow shades and light up a cig! 

Service here was fantastic, and the barista who served me, you can tell, she's a pro at what she does!
author: Edwin R.

description: Great coffee, great pastries! Delicious Cuban pastries. Service is always amazing, great, friendly vibe. Highly recommend!
author: Richard V.

description: My favorite coffee shop in the Mission! The baristas are friendly and the service is amazing. Also I love the ambiance, its small but quaint in a way and I love the decor. Best local spot.
author: Allie W.

description:
Grand Coffee is the Trillest cafe in the mission. They got the fancy coffee with out the entitled ass baristas  that you see on Valencia. These fools are keep it real so if you treat them nice they will treat you nice same goes for the meanies out there. But let's talk about the goods. Coffee is ALWAYS fresh, they got the French press brewing just for you! Not to mention the shaken ice latte is hella tasty. On a hot day get the lime Ricky, they make it with bubbly water! PS try the pastries, the Pomme d'amore you will have a mouth-gasim 

Thank you bruh bruhs for keeping it fresh and all the pendejadas you say
author: Alexa T.

description:
Literally as good as it gets. This is the most delicious coffee and lacks the pretension that so many places in The Mission have. It feels very community oriented, you can chat with the baristas and other folks at the counter. 

My favorite story was one morning in the summertime a young kid came into work the bar and the older barista said "hey did you remember to tell your mom you were coming in? She came looking for you last time and you got me in trouble!" It was just such a sweet, well-natured interaction. I love this place!
author: Sonia M.

description:
Hands down the best coffee on the Mission. I specially love their almond latte! 

Pro tip: ask them to give you a drop of their cardamom flavoring essence for that extra flavor kick in your coffee.
author: Mrignayani C.

description: Fact is i was lured into the shop by the aroma, which is a compliment in my book. While waiting for my soy latte I considered purchasing one of the raw juices but then the coffee was ready and the barista recommended I try one of the juices with some seltzer water in the future, so I figured there's always next time. As for the latte, it tasted a little weak, a bit watered down. I actually love Four Barrel prepared anywhere else but Four Barrel (they always burn it!) and the barista prepared it well it seems...just not enough punch to really give a five star review, and that's what every cafe should try to achieve, I figure. Might give them another shot. Still curious about the raw juices after all.
author: Kristina B.

description: Small coffee shop in the neighborhood spinning cool beats amidst rows of Mexican restaurants. Love the vibe. Coffee made with care. Small place. Not a place to linger for hours but a place to drop by to say hi and get a dose of urban chic coffee in the morning.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Needed some caffeine prior to an intense game at urban putt. 

Got a drip coffee. It was terrible. Likely the worst I've ever had. 

Acidic, watered down with bits of coffee grounds.
author: Thomas B.

description: Super random coffee place on Mission in between the taquerias, cheap clothing shops, and everything else in between.  Greg and I stopped here on a random afternoon and decided to sit and hang out.  The decor here was wacky, which is basically me saying that I think it's cool.  The latte I had was poured beautifully, but Greg's iced coffee was, well, small.  Nonetheless, I enjoyed my latte, in a very quiet fashion, but with Middle Eastern music going off in the background. Other Yelp reviews indicate there were food options here, but when I visited, there were none to be found.  They must either be available only in the mornings, or ran out. Definitely an interesting place to check out if you're looking for a hipster friendly coffee shop.
author: Lisa I.

description:
Grand Coffee is just an hole in the wall but they serve great coffee. a few seats inside and out.

brew: four barrels (2.5)
-silky smooth, not bold, easy sipping

drips:
-some pastries available too.
-quick, friendly service.
author: Victor G.

description:
Pretty neat cafe in Mission, SF. The barista (maybe owner too) is very kind and saved our car from being ticketed. When we told him we were visiting SF from Chicago, he was very hospitable and friendly. 

I got a latte with sugar cane syrup in it. It had a nice subtle taste to it, very well balanced, great aroma, and I could barely even taste the espresso. 

However, the space was very tiny. It was good to grab a quick cup of coffee to refuel before exploring the artistic neighborhood.
author: Rabail S.

description:
Love this charming hole in the wall cafe!! 

Great coffee, but the fact that they serve pomme d'amore from Knead Patisserie just changes the game. 

I've always gotten great service from the baristas. 

They have almond milk and take CC with square!
author: Michelle K.

description: Barista refused to serve my boyfriend coffee because he did not use the proper lingo. How can you run a fkg business like that? The guy was so rude--but he gave me a free coffee for being nice..but it was so watery like tea! Awful experience. Awful coffee.
author: Lisa P.

description:
This is arguably the best espresso in San Francisco. It's all I drink, so I wouldn't know anything about the scones or the drip coffee, but my (Four Barrel?) espresso is always rich, rounded, winey and has fine crema.
Plus, Nabeel is a truly good guy with some truly good conversation.
author: Rishad P.

description: This is a fun little "hidden gem" in the heart of the Mission, and actually ON Mission street.  If you're trying to escape from the crazies walking by, stop in and relax with a cool cup of Joe.  If you're feeling a bit more adventurous, then you should try the classic NY style Egg Creme.  It'll take you back, trust me.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Quality brews, convenient location, but steep prices. 

I'm well familiar to expensive coffee. Price is a often than not a good indicator for the quality of bean, the cafe uses for the drink item. Grand Coffee has excellent beans, and quite strong to boot. 

I've been coming here on and off for about a month while I've been working in the area. My usual is the mocha. They do not add any sugar, which is a little absurd to me, but probably because to give the customer control of the sugar content. 

I also had the chance to order the Brooklyn Egg Cream, but I didn't like it. Why would anyone want to drink chocolate flavored soda water is beyond me? It doesn't have the texture of chocolate, the richness of chocolate...just the flavor essence of it. For $3, I'd rather melt down my own chocolate bar. 

The pastries look delicious, but I have yet to try any. 

If you live or work in the Mission, this is a nice hidden gem in the midst of the bustling traffic and noise of the area. This is not a place to study, while you have a couple of coffee. There are a few tables and chairs outside, but probably only enough space to finish your cup and go.
author: Joanna S.

description:
What a hole-in-the-wall kind of coffee place!  It's not only divey, but very hipster indeed!  

Paper cranes are hung above and hipster decor are on the sides of this small caffe shoppe.  Limited seats to lounge here comfortably.  The couple of seats outside doesn't offer a grand view of Mission and it is quite cramped inside.

I got their Brooklyn Egg Cream for $3 flat and it was interesting - carbonated water mixed with chocolate.  Something different that is topped with soda foam, but it lacked refreshing taste to it. 

That's the only beverage that stood out to me on the menu and I believe I would go somewhere else for my coffee/espresso appetite!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
THIS PLACE!

Every time I've gone here there's only ever been one person working and I've always been greeted and served within seconds. Less than three minutes after that I'm holding a nice cup of tasty coffee. I work at a different cafe so I know that that is no simple task! Well done!

The chalkboard out front is also an amazing touch!
author: Tony K.

description: I got an iced soy latte. They shake it in a metal shaker with ice. The entire drink was so nice and cold without being watered down. The staff was very nice and the decor was super cute and urban. I loved my whole experience.
author: Jennifer I.

description: We were walking on mission st in San francisco, when we pass next to a quaint little coffee shop named Grand Coffee, quite ironic based on its size. The clerks were easy going and the coffee was a delicious blend from Columbia. The experience was one of those that only happens when least expected. There's nothing like coffee shops the city.
author: Zac H.

description:
Yesterday I came to visit this brand new gourmet coffee shop stand on Mission street (near 23rd St). http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/mMykGrQE-TkOFJZ4-lozyQ/l Just look for the canopy with the 60s Avant Garde lettering, which stands out among all the Latino shops nearby.

They use Four Barrel coffee, same as Dynamo. I like that coffee, but I came to try the egg cream ($2.75). An east coast drink seldom found in the bay area. I highly recommend it. It was refreshing and more delicious than Madam Bubbles version. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/iBUQVTtEL_HGk4PAKPbOow/l

They have the usuals: espresso, macchiato, cappuccino, americano, latte and mocha - all at very reasonable prices ($2-$4). Plus lemonade and limeaid ($2.75). All hot drinks can also be made as cold and frothy versions. The owner Nabeel, was super friendly. He used to work at Foreign Cinema, just a block away.

Cash only.
author: Luis C.

description: A hidden gem in the mission. Hidden because it's so small and a gem because they serve Four Barrel coffee and make the best cappuccinos!! They also make the best mocha I've ever tasted. They use really good cocoa so they don't have to put excessive amounts of sugar in it to make it taste good. The croissants are the perfect combination of buttery and flakey. I pass this place every morning on my way to work and it takes all the self control I have not to stop in every day.
author: Sarah F.

description:
I just started working in the Mission and was frantic for a tasty, strong cup of joe for when I work super freaking early assed mornings.  I know that coffee shops are a dime a dozen in this hood, however, most in the Mission tend to turn me off due to their customer service having the warmth of a Frappucino.  I am delighted I tried Grand Coffee because the coffee is excellent and the staff is lovely (and cute... caffeine and cute is always nice).  They offer four barrel coffee, served to perfection, no frills just good coffee.  They also serve non-coffee drinks that are amaze!  Yes the Egg Cream is the best I've had since living in the "Borscht Belt" of LA, however I'm hooked on the Lime Rickey.  A refreshing lime soda, perfect for these weird hot days we've been having.

I highly recommend this place to my friends, thus I would to those on the interwebs!  

P.S. The copy of "Soul on Ice" in the corner took me over the edge of adoration!
author: Anita O.

description: Good Place, Great coffee. Not a place you can sit down and enjoy your coffee, but a great place to get a coffee and go to work.
author: Polo R.

description:
Strolling down Mission St. and seeking caffeine, I spotted a cute tiny coffee place with a walk up window. They serve Four Barrel Coffee and specialty housemade drinks like egg cream and limeade. The selection of pastries was limited (cookies, croissants). They also carry raw chocolate from Fearless Chocolate.

My latte ($3.50) was excellent - smooth with deep flavor. The foam artwork showed skill. Service was exceptionally friendly. The bacon wrapped hot dog cart is right outside.

I still don't understand why some coffee places, like Grand Coffee, do not carry non-fat or low-fat milk, and only have one drink size. You can either get whole milk or soy milk and the drinks are medium size.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Tiny little espresso bar, that actually has a little space to sit inside. Cute. They serve Four Barrel, and they serve it very well. For you non milk drinkers, they have both almond and soy, and do an excellent job foaming the soy for your latte - perfect microfoam. They also use some kind of delicious dark chocolate for mochas - not too sweet. 
They also have your usual selection of cookies and pastries. 
They didn't have nonfat milk when we went (only whole); not sure if that's typical.
author: Don H.

description: Tucked in the heart of the mission, this places has exquisite coffee! The cappuccinos hit the spot and their lattes are consistently mastering the adequate balance between milk and coffee. As for pastries, my favorite is the chocolate chip cookie---great pick me up treat! The staff are also very friendly, which goes great with the morning cup of joe!
author: Daniela U.

description: Hole in the wall coffee shop in Mission. Coffee is delicious - source is Four Barrel. Well trained barista, proud of his creations. Beats Philz!
author: Andy D.

description: Cool little spot. I ordered a mocha. Barista almost yelled, "I don't have chocolate ". Normally any other coffee shop I've been to will mention something like, I don't have chocolate but maybe you'd like this other coffee/blend. He was short-tempered and rude. I walked out of there. Like I mentioned, cool spot. Maybe you'd have more patrons if he was a bit friendlier.
author: Sara A.

description:
Love this place. Even though I've been living in the mission for years, only started stopping by here recently. And I don't know why I don't more often.

Best part is the guys who work there. Nice. Friendly. Quick. Efficient. Amazing.

Got a croissant this AM, which is provided by the Local Eatery (place next to Philz). 

Thanks guys- keep rocking.
author: Kate A.

description:
Excellent place, great brews, fast & courteous service.

I usually just go here on the weekend, grab a cup of drip, and I'm out the door in 30 seconds. However, you can also just hang out front or inside and chat people up if you want. If I'm hanging out I'll tip, but if I'm in/out I usually just swipe my card (no tip) and leave.

Great spot, you should visit it :)
author: Nick E.

description: I enjoyed the espresso here the one time I did have it. The prices are reasonable and people nice. However, do not arrive at 7 (the time they are supposed to open) expecting them to be ready to make coffee. This morning, the barista didn't even arrive until 7:10. Most of us are on tight schedules in the morning, something they should take into account when they post their hours.
author: Brian S.

description: I stumbled upon this spot a couple of months ago and loved it. They serve Four Barrel and it's amazing. I also like the vibe of the small space. It's cozy. A great spot to get good coffee.
author: Rick R.

description: Great place for a relaxing break. Not good for doing work. A tiny spot with a knowledgeable and responsive owner. Limeade was perfect! Cute decor makes the experience
author: Marianna P.

description:
Best cappuccino I've ever had. I always leave it unsweetened. I come to the mission on business and I'm happy as long as I get my fix! 

The baristas are always super friendly and the drinks are consistently great, what more could you ask for?

I only wish there was one in Portland next to my house!
author: E C.

description:
New fave in the hood. So friendly and unpretentious even though they do way better coffee than the overhyped sppts in the Mission. Tiny in the best way possible...not the place to come when you're pretending you're swamped working on your next start up. But damn good coffee. And they have Califia almond milk.
#sotiredofritual
author: Shelley N.

description:
A blink-and-you'll-miss-it tiny, indie shop with amazingly tasty coffee, pastries, and my personal favorite: soy lattes.

What? When in Mission, do as the hipsters do, right?

Right.
author: Adena B.

description: We were walking on mission st in San francisco, when we pass next to a quaint little coffee shop named Grand Coffee, quite ironic based on its size. The clerks were easy going and the coffee was a delicious blend from Columbia. The experience was one of those that only happens when least expected
author: Sandro M.

description: Bomb coffee. Great pastries, easy and fast. Cute little hole in the wall that definitely is a Mission staple.
author: Jenn T.

description: Possibly the worst coffee I've ever had. Tastes like it was leftover from an AA meeting in a church basement somewhere. $2.75 fora small coffee that's watery and acidic and tastes like scalded cat urine? Never again.
author: Brian O.

description:
Despite only one Yelp! check in, I've been here several times.  I've been disappointed each time.  I waited to review until I felt I had a decent sample size.  In short:

Ritual Roasters is just a couple blocks away, go there.

Grand Coffee has very nice people working there.  But that's not worth $2.50 for *pre-brewed* drip cofee that tastes watery.  That's not worth the cost of an Americano that tastes weak.

I'm not sure what it is about the beans they use or the grinder or what, but the overall flavor is desperately lacking.  When you charge absurd hipster prices for what tastes equivalent to most corner store cups of coffee,  you are ripping off your customers.

The lattes, americano, and drip coffee are all uniformly bad.  I've had 4 different people serve me in the store; it's either a universal issue with how they're instructed to prepare the drinks, or some kind of issue with poor quality beans.  

And, seriously, I am still shocked that they have the gall to charge $2.50 for a cup of PRE-BREWED, SITTING IN A CARAFFE, WEAK COFFEE.  Ritual Roasters charges for an "as you order" individual drip cup of coffee from quality beans.  I can name several other coffee places in the Mission and around the city that do the same.  Dear Grand Coffee, those other stores can charge that much because they give you a quality cup of coffee.  Grand's coffee just tastes weak and watery.  That goes for espresso based drinks AND the what they pass off as drip coffee, which has been sitting in a caraffe heating the oils.

If Grand decreased all it's prices by a buck, I'd consider going back, because that's closer to what you're paying for.  But even then, I'm not sure I'd want what they make.

Also...for everyone raving about the pastries...you guys know they just buy them from in the neighborhood, right?  They don't make them.  Pastries bought from another local, neighborhood place doesn't mean they make good coffee.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Oh god, my friend told me that there is a four barrel coffee in my neighborhood, he got me when he said "four barrel", ive lived around the area for almost years and i just found out now. Love this place, looks like im gonna be a regular here. 

The barista that ive had, 2 so far is great, welcoming and makes great coffee. Awesome way to start my day.
author: Cavin T.

description:
Everything I want in an espresso bar
not a thing I don't.

Petite. 
Like moi.

No space for laptop distractions. 
Just you and your caffeine and maybe a partner in crime.

Order outside. Take it for a stroll down Mission.
Come inside, cozy up to the bar.

Four Barrel + La Marzocco perfection. Knead. Bike Basket. Clover.
Names you know. Friends you support. Community you believe in.

Egg cream. No egg. No cream.

Service. It exists. Return the favor.
Smile more. 
Savor your cup. Savor your day. Spread the word.
author: Alissa A.

description:
Had a reversal of opinions on this place. Whenever I've been back, I've had generally lovely service. And I've localized my original dislike of the coffee to their mass-made French-press-drip coffee, which tastes a little stale and thick and cardboardy to me.

But most everything else is quite good, and what with the cute decor and the frothy shaken iced coffees and the really super delicious baked goods (except on Mondays), Grand's a winner.
author: Sasha K.

description: Super friendly staff.Excellent coffee,strong like I need it! Cramped layout but it's perfect for on the go rocket fuel.
author: Lauren V.

description:
I really wanted to like this coffee, but when I tried it, it was terrible.

There's a lot of folks raving about their espresso, but I'm not sure why. As an immigrant from Italy, I know what a good coffee is supposed to taste like, theirs is bitter and tannic. That kind of flavor is the tell-tale sign of poor technique by the barista.

The service was just ok, but frankly I don't care about it as long as the coffee is good. 

The problem here is that the coffee is mediocre. If they improve it I'll be happy to try them again and change my rating.
author: Luca C.

description: Rude. Hipster. Dudes. Latte was great but not worth the smug vibe. I walked in on the heels of another person, and the (non-barista) guy immediately asked my order. When I replied that I thought the person ahead of me was maybe first, he said: "I know what I'm doing here. So what's your order." I won't be back, though the actual barista was nice.
author: Maryam M.

description: Owner has THE worst attitude. When asked a simple question about why there are no sleeves in the shop, the guy quickly became combative. I've gone here several times out of convenience but after this awful experience I will gladly go out of my way to go elsewhere.
author: Justin W.

description:
A recent morning, as I was ordering my coffee, I made a comment about the geometric patterns of the new scone and baked goods display case on the counter. Within a few exchanges of banter with the owner and some customers, the conversation turned to the Guggenheim in Bilbao and modern architecture in general. 

Me: "I feel like I've been transported to a salon in Paris."

Customer exchanging banter: "It's just another morning at Grand Coffee."

It is indeed. Great way to start the day.

Oh, and the coffee is great too!
author: Gunter M.

description:
If you get off of BART and are heading south, then this is your spot for a quick, legitimately brewed cup of four barrel coffee. A great french press brewed throughout the day and apparently rotated frequently.

Dude was mad chill. Some regulars walked in to get espresso/capp type drinks and loved the dude. Store front is compact with unique, artsy additions. Loved the high stools at the bar and how dude has a window that opens to the street (I think, I was day drinking on payday, hehe). Good vibe overall. 

Not a pour-over, but not a pour-over price. I do my own pour-over, so when I buy coffee out and on the go, I'm trying to get a decent cup priced just above, say, the Starbucks price but well-below the one-at-a-time pour over price you find at the big names in town, although Four Barrel does also an economical French press by the cup, as well. Whatever, that's not by 24th BART. Peace.
author: Benjamin W.

description:
This tiny little coffee shop is fantastic.  The staff are super friendly and the regulars are treated exceptionally well with excellent banter.

It's super tiny so you have to squeeze in but the coffee makes it well worth it.
author: Mark S.

description:
Yummy iced coffee, consistently good.

This place is in my neighborhood and it's really convenient to pick up some freshly roasted four barrel beans and a quick something lovely to drink.

They play really good music and are quite passionate about the neighborhood they serve and remember your face. It's a great place to be a regular, I always get a cozy feeling in my chest when they remember my order.

There's some odd items like an egg cream and a lime aid, it adds some charming Brooklyn flair! It's really rare I get one of their "specialty" items but it's nice to know that they're there if I should ever have an inconsolable egg cream craving.

Thanks Grand Coffee!
author: Lisa Q.

description: A tiny coffee shop in the mission with a bright personality. When I say tiny, I mean tiny. Probably four customers can fit in there at any given time. The upside, cheery friendly service with fresh brewed Four Barrel coffee, what more can you ask for.  I have a feeling that I will be stopping by here a lot.
author: Charles L.

description: Grand Coffee, top 5 best coffee in SF, is a small coffee shop with 4 seats only. It takes Four Barrel as roasters. The shot tasted so strong, not my type but was tasty in layers. That's not an easy thing to make espresso with such clear-layer tastes.
author: Wei-Hsiang H.

description:
Finally, I've found my staple neighborhood coffee shop!

Grand Coffee serves 4 barrel coffee and is only two people, the proprietor and some hired help for Mondays. It's not Grand in the sense of physical presence; I usually have to double back to find it.

The delicious, deep layer of crema on the americano I grab in the mornings is the stuff coffee dreams are made of. And the lattes I've tried were ridiculously frothy and delicious (especially the iced versions!)

I usually brew my own coffee, but I haven't bought beans in a while because they'd go stale while I shun them for Grand Coffee.
author: Alan F.

description: I used to walk by this place on my way to work often without giving it a second thought. I finally swung by (on my last day) to try the egg cream (which was weird) but I found the shop to be very cute and cozy... it felt safe (as I'm always paranoid walking down mission) and I liked that feeling of warmth/cozy atmosphere. The barista was pleasant and gave me the backstory on egg cream. Charming! I'd check it out if you live around the area.
author: Samantha D.

description:
I often forget about this small spot, but when work takes me to this block of Mission, I am always pleased when I take a ten minute break at the counter and sip a Grand Coffee.

Eavesdropping to lively behind the counter banter is a great way to get out of your own workday and into Mission chatter.  And if you want to jump in, Nabeel is happy to have you in the conversation.

Love them!

PS - Great non-laptop cafe;  I get antsy when so many people are working during my 10 minute break!
author: Rudy R.

description: Excellent coffee from four barrel. Small, cute coffee place with super laid back and friendly staff.
author: Jahnvi P.

description:
I really wanted to like this coffee ... and I did! 

I was in a hurry. I was looking for a store on Mission that had in fact moved since I was last there (as I was later to discover) and I was tired and cranky. I needed a macchiato and got so much more: a quiet moment in the shade in the presence of a non-horrible hipster barrista. Not only was the macchiato served promptly and prepared perfectly but he also gave me a shot of seltzer as a chaser: an unforeseen bit of mixology that made the whole experience even more rejuvenating.
author: V. J. L.

description:
My favorite coffee in the City. It reminds me of Portland (where I used to live). It is tiny and the decor is rad. 

BIG FAN!
author: Gina H.

description:
"Tupac and Coffee?  Good God it's Christmas morning".  

Lets be real.  Starbucks coffee is gross.  It's bitter.  Just try drinking it without all the syrups, chocolate and whip cream in it and you'll find out quick.  They've done terrible in several nationwide taste tests, even being rated lower than some decafs.  Grand Coffee saves us from bad coffee.

I'm not a morning person so I dont want a lot of chit chat especially if I didn't have my coffee yet.  It's good strong coffee, and the espresso is fantastic.  

The music and vibe is great.  You will get the snobs along with the regular people and that's cool with me.  

The pastries are fresh and very good.  They have unique things like creme brulee cake, and pop tarts made out of ricotta with basic pastries that are fresh and good.  No offense but the pop tarts are brutal but some seem to like it.  

They have egg creme.  My best friend is from the bronx and he said it sucked and said they didn't prepare it right.  We laid back Californians know how uptight some New Yorkers can be so I decided to try it.  I didn't like it at all.  It's not for everyone. 

Service was fast and polite.  

I still in my right mind don't know why people go to overpriced starbucks when there are great locally owned coffee shops all over serving up some great coffees at lesser prices.  SUPPORT YOUR LOCAL COFFEE SHOPS!  

Pros:
-great coffee 
-coffee is still a rip off but compared to starbucks and other chains it's at a good price. 
-great pastries
-fast friendly service

Con's:
-not a fan of the egg cream or the ricotta pop tart
-it's pretty busy


**What has more caffeine?  Espresso or Regular coffee? 
-Depending on the coffee, espresso has 30-50 mg caffeine per fluid oz.
-Regular coffee has 8.1 to 15 mg caffeine per fluid oz.  

Espresso has much more caffeine per oz, but what is interesting is that most people drink a much larger amount of coffee per serving than espresso. 

If you have a 2 oz. espresso for 100 mg of caffeine, but have a 8 oz coffee, you will be getting 120 mg of caffeine.  Obviously for a 12 oz cup you will be getting 180 mg of caffeine. 

Caffeine also allows for aspirin and other pain killers to work faster and that's why some even have caffeine in it.  

Caffeine is also a METHYLXANTHINE and has bronchodilation properties, like asthma drugs.  Caffeine is interesting!
author: JMark P.

description: I'm honestly not sure what the good reviews are for this place (maybe their espresso is out of this world?) but the first time I went here, my iced coffee tasted like simple syrup and water and the second time I decided to go, my regular coffee had coffee sediment on the bottom. This wasn't just a little bit of it either - the whole bottom of the cost was coated in what almost looked like chocolate syrup. Seeing that explained why the coffee tasted like shit too. Overall just a disappointing place. Ambiance is cool I guess, but it's very small inside the shop. If you want good coffee, go elsewhere in the mission.
author: Keith P.

description: I might have been the first customer of the day . I'm the smart one that parties on a school night. This has become my go-to spot whenever I leave the mission district during the wee hours of the morning. I like how my coffee was made with a french press. Cute, right? The owner is super nice and he's also a bartender at foreign cinema with one of my favorite bartenders from the layover. You should pay them  both a visit and tip them nicely. Support local business owners!
author: Hannah A.

description: no discount for bringing your own mug? we frown upon this. otherwise a no-frills coffee shop. four barrel is decent
author: Loren B.

description:
* Clean, fresh little spot. Check!
* Friendly, nice and charismatic proprietor. Check!
* Original refreshing menu. Check!



Tuesday I stumbled upon this gift from the coffee gods. When I walked in the first thing that popped into sight was the, "Brooklyn egg cream" and will be back to try everything else. Some argue there are too many caffeine refueling stations the city although the more shops the more likely the cream will rise to the top. This little shop will rise to the top. There is no reason to not give 5 stars. Excellent friendly personal service in a great location

Go here now! This little spot is worthy of a ride out to the Mission.
author: Justin S.

description:
I stumbled upon this place this afternoon while on my lunch break in the Mission. Now, as I settle back in to my routine at the office, my mind is still on the deeply satisfying, silky and rich cappuccino that I got at Grand Coffee. And I'm already anticipating my next visit- it was that good!

Though the operation is small and caters to carry-away customers, there is a small counter where you can sit and enjoy your coffee and perhaps a conversation with Nabeel, the proprietor, who is a very friendly guy. Ask about the decorative wood and tile accents  he's affixed to the walls; Nabeel restored these elements by hand and clearly has an eye for details. He's made a beautiful space out of the old theater in which the kiosk is located. This level attentiveness is evident in the quality of the coffee, as well! I will definitely be back.
author: Mark N.

description: Hip. Divey. Great coffee. I don't normally feel cool, but I feel way less cool when I order coffee here. There is seating inside and out, but I always get my drinks to go. I would definitely recommend getting some coffee here!
author: Chase L.

description: Good strong coffe, served quick with no fuss or attitude. In an awkward small spot on Mission to get to but convenient if walking.
author: Livia M.

description:
Discovered after going to Sun Fat. Small, intimate and welcoming. The guys who own and run this gem in the mission are friendly and helpful, plus serving my all time have, Four Barrel. I get a cup and sit on the sidewalk watching people on an early Saturday morning before Mission wakes.  This is one of those moments that make me love the city as much as I do.

Great selection of pastries and bags of Four Barrel without the 5 - 10 minute wait. Can't beat it!

I'm a huge fan!
author: Steve S.

description: This place is awesome.  It's small, so you have to talk to the other people inside.  Everyone that works there is super friendly.  They have the best cappuccino, and I had plenty of them since I worked a block away.  Of all the wonderful coffee shops in SF, this is by far my favorite.
author: Bennett H.

description:
Perfect. Serves consistently well brewed Four Barrel. Adorable staff and setting (for the little joint that it is.

Love making a pit stop here our way to a brunch line somewhere on the weekend.
author: Sue C.

description: This is the best iced coffee I've ever had. I don't know what they do to it or even how to describe it, it's just delicious. Also every time I've been there the baristas have known almost everybody by name, which is really nice in a city this big.
author: Sara G.

description: Best coffee in the mission!  Try the brooklyn egg cream too
author: E G.

description: Found this little gem on a random morning while walking around in the mission. Really good coffee...but you gotta grab it to go because there is nowhere to sit. The staff was friendly and very efficient.
author: George M.

description: It's a really tiny place. i heard they serve the best brooklyn egg cream, so i came all the way here for a try. it turns out that i don't like it  :( it tastes so strange to me with soda and chocolate syrup. there is a lot of bubble at the top. when the bubble sinks, it only has half a cup left, so i don't think it's worthy :(
author: Ashley C.

description: I wuv this place! It's my first to go place before classes start. I need my morning jolt of mocha and it's soooo good! The staff is super friendly. I wuv the hearts they make on each drink! Soooo cute! The pastries are literally to die for --specially the creme brûlée tart! Holy mackerel! That thing just melts in your mouth with all the awesome gooeyness! Yum! Yum! Yummiest!
author: Jello B.

description:
Grand Coffee is great! It's right by my office and the guys who run the place know me by name.  (I like that.)

I'm a latte kind of gal and they always make mine perfectly.  They have a variety of other drinks too.  I recommend the Lime Ricky, it's a great afternoon refresher.
author: Margaret I.

description:
I've been here 2x's. 

First time got a regular drip. It was--meh. 

Second time, soy latte. As drinks come in ONE size I was shocked by the price of $4.25, taste--ok.

I wish I could hang out, but inside is teeny tiny :-(
author: Hilda Z.

description: Great little place with lots of character and a killer espresso. Had to refrain the girlfriend from trying to steal the cups.
author: Sam S.

description: I work in the Mission had seen this place which is a tinny hole in the wall but conveniently located.  Going back from a walk decided to get a coffee for the after lunch pick me up.  Worst coffee I have tried.  It was not hot at all, very bad flavor and it even had bits of grain in it.  Way to much money to pay for something so bad.
author: Sabrina H.

description: Was in sanfrancsio ... Best coffee ever ...and great Servic  and would definitely recommend to stop by if u are in the area
author: Ayesha K.

description:
Let me keep this simple in case you haven't had your coffee yet:

Lemon Ricotta pop tart.

Creme Brulee cake.

4 Barrel Coffee (not many places have it.  And yes, they are trained by 4 Barrel).

Perfect size space, very clean, and the owner Nabil is there on site, at least 6 days a week.

Interior design has some subtle details that are gorgeous if you are paying attention.

It is on Mission Street, and everyone from snooty coffee junkie, to Mission street junkie, attend and appreciate the quality craft emanating from Grand Coffee.

Did I mention the place was swarming with beautiful women of all walks of life? Nothing to do with coffee, but definitely a great way to start ones day.

And anyone who can play Tupac with such class so early in the morning, I am a fan of.
author: Carlos N.

description: About once a week I come here to get some caffeine to fuel my body and start the day, their coffee may not be the best one but it keeps me awake during the rest of the day. I love getting my coffee here while I use my computer but lately the internet connection has been really slow and that has forced me to look for different alternatives. I hope this gets fixed soon because I rather stay here.
author: Pepi R.

description: These people know what they're doing, and that's good because they only do one thing: good coffee. Focus is good. Outstanding espresso--a great way to start a day in the Mission District! It is truly a hole in the wall, though, so don't expect to hang around. Better than the others in the neighborhood.
author: Rich M.

description:
I make at least three visits a week, since I first tried a cup of coffee in October 2010. Extremely friendly guys, great coffee, great pastries* and enough interesting tidbits of conversation to catch and update your facebook statuses until hell freezes over.

*Good God! The pastries are amazing, especially the crème brûlée one. When I tried one my mouth just broke into a smile followed by an obligatory "mmmohhmmmmgoooooodmmmm"

it was really that tasty.
author: Alais d.

description: This is the most consistent coffee in the Mission. It's small and welcoming. Nabil, the owner, is often behind the counter and the rest of the staff are also personable and friendly. They make the best Cortados! Not to mention, they sometimes house Local Mission Eatery's Pomme De Amores--which go great with any drink.
author: cara t.

description:
Philz has the whole coffee brewed fresh to order thing down but what if you occasionally want an espresso drink?

After they refused to sell us after brunch coffee at Foreign Cinema (up coming review will not please some people) the waiter suggested we go to this place. 

This guy makes a great macchiato. All of his shots are doppio ristretto (double restricted) so they are all intensely flavorful with beautiful crema.

Most people don't know this about me but for a year about 15 years ago I worked for a hard-core Italian coffee company with some serious Italian experts that turned into a crash course. The drink I had at Grand Coffee reminded me of something my old boss said to me once; imagine this said with a thick accent, "Coffee isn't supposed to be bitter, life is already bitter enough"
author: Manny F.

description:
The first americano I've ever had where the finish was almost better than the start. Just absolutely great espresso, small tiny vibe, and a block up from the Mission/24 Bart station.

They have Square, so you can use your credit card, though I've always used cash.
author: Jeff M.

description:
5 stars for the service, 5 stars for the product, 5 stars for the creativity, 4 stars for the venue.. although I also like the feel of the place for a date or after date or something like that... 

I usually use coffee shops to sit and read or study so, it wouldn't be ideal for me. Why did I come here then? We were walking around this area, striking out at almost every place we stopped (closed that day, not open until 5 pm for dinner, didnt have cold beer for their happy hour). We came across this very inconspicuous place and decided to try it out. 

It looks like a bar, and serves coffee. The owner seems very passionate and creative with the way he makes the drinks. He made if a special iced-coffee that was really delicious... and he had a limeade specialty drink. He sells those mini cupcakes (that I will yelp about next). Everything overall was great for a quick stop. Love it... wish it was closer or had seating to study!
author: Sirina K.

description:
Good coffee, poor egg cream .

Espresso drinks where well prepared.  Owner was friendly enough and provided interesting conversation.  I'd give 4 stars for the coffee.

But, he was offering egg cream.  I grew up in NY, so was eager to try one.  Not right.  Owner didn't grow up drinking them and is giving it a shot.  Maybe he's improved by now (I haven't tried one in a few months).

Nice, comfortable, small space.  Good addition to the area.
author: Jice E.

description:
Sometimes I just want an expertly made coffee without the frills, and that's exactly what I was swiftly delivered when a quick search of my surroundings while apartment hunting near 24th & Mission led me here. I wasn't in the mood for an extra walk to Four Barrel Coffee, but oh boy, did I ever crave a cappuccino made with their beans.

The owner at Grand Coffee whipped one up for me made with FBC beans at $1 off (just for mentioning Yelp) - a sweet bonus, and I loved every molecule within my 8 ounce cup. No extra accoutrements required - this was one perfect cappuccino for a finicky caffeine addict like me. While I waited, he poured me some sparkling water for sipping and palate cleansing before handing over my heavenly brew.

This isn't a sitdown place - in fact, I almost thought it was a walk-up window as I approached. So stay for a quick chat with the friendly owner, but move along if you're looking for wifi or a spot to spread out with your stuff. 

I didn't find my dream apartment on this particular visit to The Mission, but finding a gem like Grand Coffee makes me think I need to step up my search for one in the 'hood!
author: Kat F.

description:
I just moved back to SF from Portland, so have become a coffee snob. Two things make a good latte for me: 
-that the latte is hot enough
-that the foam and milk are separated in the cup, resulting in a 12 oz beverage, not a 4 oz one. 

This shop pours a great latte, the best I've had in town yet. I'm gluten free so I havent tried the pastries, but they look good. 
I'm so glad Grand Coffee exists.
author: Sailor H.

description:
After reading about the Egg Creams on a blog, I decided to seek out this tiny coffee spot.  I decided to skip right to my drug of choice.  My latte was very delicious and the fellas working there were very friendly.

Though it's not a place to sit and read or ponder your future.  It's a "get an awesome coffee and get on with it" sort of place.

Definitely seek this place out if you are a self proclaimed coffee junkie.  I imagine that their Egg Creams are to die for... will most definitely be back for one of those in the future, too.
author: Miranda O.

description: The Grand is an awesome establishment. The owner Nabeel is very knowledgeable about coffee and if there isnt a line out the door, he is down to chat coffee. I personally think he extracted my espresso better than some of the barista's at Four Barrels Roasterie and The Mill. With attention to detail like that it is no wonder he is doing so well. Props
author: John S.

description:
I found a tiny tiny coffee shop! You can too!

If you're in the Mission and looking for a quick caffeine jolt, try this new spot that opened in summer '10. 

We were able to score two of three stools inside, and chat with the owner for a bit. It was like sitting at your favorite neighborhood bar, except it had pleasant smells and only two other people in the room. It gets a little loud when the espresso machine fires up, so it's not a place to reflect or be emo, which I concur is fun to do in a coffee shop at times. Instead, it's a good place to park yourself for a few minutes and be friendly. 

Of course, if you choose to get your coffee to go, how can you not love the charm and convenience of the actual order window that is accessed from the sidewalk? It gives you a similar thrill to the concession stand window at the public pool when you were a kid. 

We tried the lattes, which were complex and strong, thanks for Four Barrel's beans, yet perfectly balanced. I couldn't turn away a Mission Mini cupcake, which was showcased in the tiniest, cutest, Alice in Wonderland-esque cake stand I've ever seen.

Great find!
author: Jill C.

description:
The cafe just opened on July 1st and though most people take their coffees to go, there are a couple of bar stools for those who wish to imbibe at a more relaxed pace.

The wonderful rich & silky cappuccino was done perfectly, & I loved the unique touch of a shot of refreshing seltzer water to follow. Organic milk at no extra charge (hurrah!), a place with history behind it, and a charming proprietor who takes considerable pride in his work, and in putting down roots in the neighborhood he works in.

A great addition to Mission St, and we wish Nabeel the best! We'll definitely be back!
author: Sharand N.

description:
Old school flavor with new school funk.

This cafe is quality and the owner serves up the best cappuccinos around. Very simple and refreshing menu, organic milk for all at no extra charge, shot glass of seltzer with in-house espresso drink, signature beverages including lime aids and "Brooklyn egg creams".  

Bar seating and tasty, locally-made treats coming soon. Prior to that, have a drink standing (as the Italians do) while chatting with the owner, who happens to have a very witty sense of humor.
author: Kristen R.

description: Yeah maybe a bit hipster for me but solid nonetheless.  On my walk to my office from bart so it is good - i get an americano with some steamed milk - but also very convenient for me.   Coffees are pretty pricey for the size but taste really good.  Id say its as good as any other coffee in the hood.
author: Josh V.

description:
What a great coffee shop. It is small but unique. I love the canopy outside, the corked walls and brushed wood. It is funky with delicious Four Barrell coffee. This is my new place to start the day. 

Nabil, the owner is awesome. I cant wait to try the egg cream. He described it to me and it sounds very refreshing! A midday pick me up...The best part the besides the great service and delicious coffee, the prices are fair!
author: Rachna P.

description:
This place put a smile on my face.  It's a cute, shiny little spot directly on Mission street.  Really perks up that block.

They brew Four Barrel, use Cloverfield organic milk, offer soy, and also do egg creams, which is so unique and so unheard of in San Francisco!  I had a yummy latte, but have to go back to try the egg cream  just for the nostalgia:  My grandfather grew up in Brooklyn and would fix me the occasional egg cream as a treat.  He would say to me:  "Egg cream - no egg, no cream!"

They've only been open for only 17 days - go and check it out!
author: Erica K.

description: New to the Bay Area, Grand is very close to where I am staying.  I tried to get a cup of their four barrel drip but kept striking out: There too early, there on a day deliveries were not in yet, there too late.  Each time the owner/barista was very pleasant, but I'll admit it was awkward refusing an Americano each time.  I just can't stand drinking a watery espresso; I'm Italian! I was pleased with the coffee once I had it, though. And I am hooked! Great place to make new friends, too.
author: Kiki V.

description:
We all know that there are a gazillion coffee shops that claim that they are the freaking best.

Grand Coffee - no decoration, no advertising budget, no hustle/bustle of typical coffeehouses.  What Grand Coffee does have - good coffeemaking apprenticeship, good beans, streamlined menu, and good smelling/tasting coffees.  Efficient and friendly service right in the heart of the mission district.

That's all I have to say.
author: Mike P.

description: This coffee literally makes my toes curl. I love it. It is manna from heaven. A single latte with the creme brulee pastery is DELISH! I try to go when ever I can 2-3xs a week....even though I live in Millbrae. I have also made my mom a firm believer in this stuff.....and she takes everyone she knows in there. the guy's are great, the mood is chill, and the coffee IS bomb.
author: Laila J.

description: Classic coffee stop, always a great brew and I enjoy the stamp on the cups.
author: Sabreena H.

description:
While the Mission isn't lacking great coffee (Ritual, Four Barrels, Haus), it's so awesome that a small coffee shop like this has opened on Mission St. More the merrier I say!

Really love the look of this place, it's tiny, it's compact, and served great coffee - Four Barrels. Reminds me of some places in Berlin, Rome and Sydney.

The owner is very friendly and knowledgeable of the coffee he serves. The latte was excellent, made just right.

Looking forward to hanging out at Grand more often and drinking my coffee right on Mission st.
author: Patrick W.

description:
I desperately needed a latte in the late afternoon after my dentist consultation and it was a nice sunny day in the Mission. I was wondering, "Now where can I find a coffee shop in this area?..." Being a frequent visitor of Starbucks and Peets Coffee, I don't normally have the pleasure of going to small independent shops (even though I should) because they're scarce in the D-Town. That's when I spotted this little place called "Grand Coffee," so I jotted across the street, risking my life for a latte. 
Once inside I was charmed by this place, everything about it screams "INDEPENDENT and "SUSTAINABLE." Immediately I was overtaken by the delicious smell of coffee beans; I proceeded to order a latte and the barista was very friendly. He was able to multi-task as he chatted with me while he expertly made the leaf design on my latte. I had never had a design on my latte before so I was very excited. 
Believe when I say that that latte was five times better than any Starbucks or Peets coffee I had ever had in my life! On the BART ride back to school I was practically PDA-ing with my latte. I was soo sad when my cup was empty because it was SO GOOD! Oh well...until next time Grand Coffee <3 <3 <3
author: Reina V.

description: Really cute and unpretentious coffee shop! Will definitely walk by other overrated coffee shops that will not be named to actually have good service and a great coffee (and mmmm pastries).
author: Ayo R.

description:
An extremely pleasant surprise. Met some friends there who had rolled in off the street randomly to this coffee shop. I had a fantastic macchiato. The beans were excellent. I'm not sure what roastery made them, but they were a pleasant medium roast; not overdone at all.

The shop is "cozy", i.e. small, but the proprietor was very congenial, and the service was quick. If you're in the neighborhood, stop by for an excellent esspresso beverage.
author: Joel W.

description: A coffee shop totally unnoticeable expect for the fact that some hipsters were sitting out in front so thought i would check it out. Cute but the gentlemen who served us was an ass and I don't repeat places where I am not treated right. I actually never ordered because of his behavior and I tried to joke around but he still never backed off with his attitude. My friend still grabbed his coffee and didn't like the quality of the americano. I won't be back.
author: Kalifornia S.

description: The owner makes the best espresso in the Mission, hands down. I haven't tried anything else here. The shot of carbonated water they give you as a palate cleanser is always appreciated too.
author: Paul J.

description:
Location location location!

I was running to the Bart station and had a NEED for coffee! I saw Grand Coffee and ran it hoping for the best, but really was just happy I wasn't going to grab something from MickieD's.

This little shop surprised me. It was cozy and cool. Definitely not the place you are going to camp out sipping a mocha for hours, but absolutely perfect for grabbing a big cup of coffee on the go.

They offered the standard fare with about the norm for coffee prices. The mocha I had was wonderful. Good flavor, made fast, good price = one happy customer.

It's nice to have another go-to coffee spot in town as I was really lacking for my 'caf' fix in this part of town.
author: Nick B.

description: Great 4 barrel coffee and the best coffee deal I've found in SF.  2 bucks for 4 barrel? Sold.  Small place, but great for a cup on the move.
author: Brian B.

description:
They do one thing, coffee, and they do it very well.

It is a sweet location, tucked into a corner of a storefront on Mission Street just steps from BART, and the space has a cozy, improvised feel without being cluttered.

I'm glad that they are doing enough business to start having multiple employees, but hope the new coffee slingers brush up on customer service skills. By that I mean if I have to choose between a smile and efficient service, I'll choose efficient service every time.

Quality and prices are phenom.
author: Bobby D.

description:
I was walking by here yesterday with an iced coffee from Philz in hand. The owner / barista offered to replace my coffee with one of his own. I normally drink espresso and so asked for espresso to replace my current coffee. The espresso was poured perfectly and used Four Barrel beans. The extra nice touch was a shot of seltzer water to chase the espresso.

It looks like they offer some specialty coffee drinks too (shaken? with Brooklyn cream?). I didn't quite understand what these were, but am willing to experiment next time based on the espresso I was served.

Note this is a coffee kiosk, not a coffee shop. I.e., don't bring your laptop with the intention of setting up and working for a few hours. This is a spend a few minutes having a coffee standing up and then move on sort of place.
author: J Y L.

description: I got off the BART at a random stop in the city on Monday morning. I walked around because I had nothing to do and it was my vacation. I walked past the storefront and smelled the fumes. I stopped in and was glad that I did so. Big Pun "I Ain't a Playa" was playing. I love Big Pun and his clever wordplay. When he says "With my balls bangin off your hymen" I just kind of feel bad because I don't think he knew what part of anatomy he was trying to reference. I think a lot of rappers need some kind of QC checks in place. Maybe hire an English major like me and I could provide guidance. Or like when Lil Wayne (who is one of the worst) said "Drive fast like Tom Petty" when in fact he meant Richard Petty. Not to say that at times Tom Petty doesn't drive fast because I am sure he does. The baristas here were mean as expected. Culture does not always have to dictate bad behavior. Love thy neighbor.
author: P W.

description:
I'm glad to have another good coffee joint on my way to BART/work.  Nabil is very friendly and knowledgeable every time I come in, and I'm excited to see how the little space changes in the weeks to come.  

Great coffee, interesting drink ideas, fair prices and good service.  What more can you ask for?
author: Aimee B.

description: Grand Coffee is an excellent place to grab high quality coffee on the way to work, just a block and a half from the 24th St. BART station.  The staff has been nice and speedy when I have gone there, and the pastries I have had were pretty good too (I have had the almond croissant and a custard filled circular thing that I had trouble not wolfing down in a single bite).  It's a hole in the wall with only minor counter/seating space, so its more of a place you looking forward to stopping by, rather than a place to linger, but they are all about making you a high quality brew that will send you back on your way with a nicely caffeinated smile.
author: Aaron S.

description: Love this spot!  There seems to be a harmonious blend of mobile devices, conversation and delicious coffee drinks!
author: Sya - 'Urban Oasis' W.

description:
I have never been the kind of guy who has NEEDED a caffeinated pick-me-up.  Coffee does it for me because of the taste and because of the additional energy it provides.  Some people drink coffee to make it through their day, I drink coffee to make my day great.

And so far, in the Mission, I have not found a coffee shop better than Grand for making my day that way!  I have a love affair with their Americanos (with beans from Four Barrel), because they have always led to a perkier morning and a great start to the day.

I also greatly appreciate that their pastries come from Knead Patisserie.  When I make a point of eating something as fattening as a butter croissant, why waste the calories on an extra six-block walk?


My gripe is their hours.  Yes, 7am is perfectly early enough for my purposes... if they actually open by then.  I have walked by the store front on many a commuter's morning, expectantly hoping that it will be one of the days that they are open and I can get my espresso.  It usually is not to be.

To the proprietors: don't change your habits just because of me, but know that you'd have an (at least) weekly customer if you were consistently open by 7!
author: Sam D.

description: Once more, a cafe seething in utter irony (Grand?). I walked past this place thinking it was a bathroom, and was proven right, amazingly, given by the tell-tale signs of urine from in front of the store and the taste of the coffee - surely I could have paid less for something I can easily siphon from my own toilet bowl. Vermin were here, as usual, looking as though they were lost and out of place, as mariachi music faded in and out, and their well-shined shoes were quickly muddied. Apparently they didn't get the memo that this isn't Paris (those aren't tanned French people drowning in poverty or in Bohemian choice outside your door, who cannot afford your coffee), and that the goddamn Impressionists were 100 years ago. Still they pretend that Monet is going to walk up to them and shake their hand and twirl their mustache and "chat." Three things I must rate for a cafe: Clientele, Courtesy, and Coffee, and this place fails all three. Sometimes I think hipsters severed their tastebuds in the name of "Art;" Zola called, he wants his beard back.
author: Peter S.

description: Coffee's perfect in this little hole in the wall. It's creamy and strong, as it should. Try the espresso, you will thank me later... Also, the pastries are very, very tasty, above all the little "pasteis". And everything is local!
author: Simone B.

description: Egg Cream, anyone? Lime Rickey? Oh yeah, latte? This is the place. My second trip. first trip I had a macchiato, perfect proportions of espresso and foam. This time it was iced coffee, made by shaking the coffee with ice. They offer only 3% milk--a.k.a. whole milk--who knew? It would be nice to have more choice in that department, but the star they would have lost for that is replaced by a star for decorating genius; spend some time paying attention to the details. Amusing baristas.
author: Beth W.

description:
Atmosphere: awesome
Staff: cool
Coffee: great

I love going to Grand Coffee!!
author: cheese r.

description:
I really like this small and unpretentious coffee place in the Mission.
Very creative interior design: reclaimed wood + clever use of old magazines (or newspapers).

Cappuccinos were excellent!
They also have baked treats (like Pomme d'Amour from Knead Patisserie), jams and very nice assortment of chocolate.
author: BO P.

description: If only this place had more seats! It's an adorable little nook of a store, great decor inside and some of the best coffee you can get. The baristas are nice and make great latte art, and if you manage to get a table outside the people-watching on Mission on a weekend morning is priceless.
author: Alyssa G.

description: This place ROCKS !!!! Great coffee and cute petite space. Bonus a couple sidewalk tables.
author: Julie B.

description: I live down the block. I love heading in there, they know what I like and the conversation that results from being there is hilarious :). I seriously can't get an americano anywhere else...the rest tastes like crap now...damnit.  Nabeel is awesome, but he needs to get me splenda! +5 extra stars for Kim too.
author: Miryam S.

description: Been here a few times now, as my girlfriend works nearby. They are always polite and prompt to get your order. Decent cup of coffee as well.. The prices are extremely low, and they've even got a lime rickey on the menu yay!
author: Terry B.

description:
Nabeel proves that you can treat coffee-making as a craft without bringing snobbery or attitude into the coffee house. I've had most everything on the menu now, and both hot and cold drinks have all been excellent.
P
You really have to check this little gem of a place out. The owner, all-around nice-guy Nabeel, is constantly making minor improvements to what is obviously a labor of love... like a new custom espresso 'cocktail' that's not on the menu or new pieces of art that seem less like art and more like they just naturally grew out of the simple but funky interior space.

Bottom line: perfect Mission location, unique and cozy environment, and a friendly owner who makes a killer cup of coffee and espresso.
author: Brick C.

description:
dollar store
99c store
grand coffee
99c store
hot dog bacon cart

finally mission between 21st and 22nd is complete. 

good coffee.
author: Roy N.

description: Fantastic iced mocha! He uses really good chocolate made in NY that he let me sample as well. Nice guy, great coffee.
author: Johnny N.

description:
There is a coffee machine at work. It's actually a rather nice one kept continually stocked with beans from Peet's. 

Every morning I ponder the tradeoff - free acceptable coffee at work, or $2 awesome 4 Barrel coffee at Grand Coffee.  

The best way to describe this place would be a mini-4 Barrel that you don't need to walk out to 14th and Valencia for. It's got the same wooden decor, the baristas worked there in the past, the beans are from there...but there's no line. Delicious.

It's just really tiny. So don't come expecting to do work or chat up a date or anything. There's a little bar-style seating with stools, and some outdoor chairs, but really not the best place to focus or have a conversation.
author: Victor L.

description: Nabeel, the visionary proprietor of Grand Coffee, doesn't fuck around with half-caff lattes and sprinkles and pumpkin soy bullshit. Leave your laptop at home. At Grand Coffee, you get authentic, no frills, bomb-ass espresso, with a shot of seltzer on the side. It's the best I've had outside the Italian motherland. I walk 20 minutes past at least ten cafes (including Blue Bottle) on the regular to get an espresso from here. If everyone in the world went about their business like Nabeel does, the heavens would crack asunder and rain Utopian glory down upon all the human race for all eternity, evermore. Amen.
author: El G.

description: If one day this corporate gig doesn't work out, I might follow the lead of the proprietor of Grand Coffee. Find a small yet functional space in the mission, brew up some potent and well priced coffee, and sit back between pours and enjoy the colorful world that is the Mission. It wouldn't be a bad alternative.
author: Jason B.

description:
Nice little spot in the middle of Mexico.

Stopped by here after trying out Zaytoon last friday.  We had a short conversation with the owner, he's a nice guy who is really into his shop. He makes his coffee drinks like he's crafting cocktails -- interesting to watch.

I had an iced americano, which was thoroughly enjoyed.

The belt-sanded panels have some beautiful color and texture in them.  I hope this shop does well.
author: Adam C.

description: OMG YES Grand Coffee is awesome. After *suffering* through a WHOLE WEEK of Ritual coffee I realized that I needed a better afternoon pickup. 4 barrel is my favorite - so when I discovered this place is basically 4b2 I quickly went to check it out. It is teeny tiny and no-nonsense. I got a cup of french press and was imPRESSED by the quality and freshness. heh.
author: M M.

description: Recommended by a friend.  It's a stylish hole-in-the wall with Four Barrel beans.  A great place for it too- modern vibe amid working-class block in the old Grand Theatre building.  They sell beans too, which is great for nearby neighbors.  Stop in for a cup in between thirft store and 99 cent store shopping....
author: Eric S.

description: SOOO GOOD! I love this place, I'm always bummed when I don't have time to stay and hang out for a while. Never bummed by the quality coffee I receive. The staff is awesome, the customers are awesome, the coffee.... ah-mazing! It feels more like visiting the local bar, all the regulars and staff know and like each other and are equally friendly  and open to new faces.
author: Jasmine T.

description: This place is the shizzzzz baby. Nabeel knows whats up. I love just going there to chill on my down time. The people that got there are some of the most random and interesting in the city. This place is starting to pick up steam cuz of  the quality of shots pulled and the kick ass service. Good job guys, keep it up.
author: Rocky Y.

description: Nabil is a great barista and super friendly. Beans from Four Barrel and pastries from Knead, random goodies for sale like local preserves, etc. too. Laid back place, great to jump in for a minute and have an espresso.
author: Timothy V.

description: Really skilled and friendly baristas without the attitude that you will occasionally experience at  other local cafés. Space is small, but still fun to sit at the bar or chairs outside and listen to whatever music they're playing. Eclectic and fun mix of customers. Most importantly good coffee. They are busy at times with a line 3 or 4 customers deep, so if in a rush you may have to keep moving or plan on going there with time to spare.
author: Wilbur K.

description: Nabeel is super friendly and makes a genuine effort to get to know people, which I apreciate. I'd love to see more healthy food options, so I'm hoping that's on its way. Definitely my new "spot."
author: Jen O.

description: Came upon this little coffee shop yesterday afternoon.  Apparently it's been around for 13 months, and I'm bummed I only just found it. Cozy and awesome, the hot chocolate was delicious, the egg cream was pretty sweet and the cookie to top it off...!  The guy there was chill, approachable... recipe for the perfect coffee/bring a book spot!
author: Kat C.

description:
First the disclaimer- I don't drink coffee.  Can't stand it. 
So this is a review of just the non-coffee options.

Mostly these awesome little custard & caramel filled pastries they have.  Which are amazing and you should try as soon as you can. The croissants are pretty good too.  

Also the hot chocolate, which is the spicy Dagoba stuff (Xocolatl).  Perfectly reasonably if you are looking for a spicy hot chocolate but also perfectly easy to make at home for yourself. *shrug*
author: saru k.

description: Loved the egg cream here! Nabil is ultra friendly and knowledgeable. The coffee was expertly made and prices were very reasonable. (2-3 bucks for most drinks) Only con is little to no seating (more of a grab and go). Highly recommended.
author: Asha R.

description: I simply hate pretentious. I'm grateful for the option to slink into Grand, in my pajamas, have a quality cup of cafe, and listen to some solid Arab-American hip hop all before 10 am. It makes me feel normal.
author: Sunny Joy B.

description: Heading to or from something near 22nd and Mission and need a quick double espresso? My heart still belongs to Philz for my lazy Sunday coffee, but Grand Coffee is the most delicious (yes, better then Ritual) and quickest place to go for coffee in the Mission. No lines and Nabeel is very, very friendly. He asks his customer questions and serves coffee without the attitude. Yay Nabeel!
author: Lisa K.

description: This is my go to coffee stall. Quick, casual, and a shot of seltzer as chaser. Also, Nabeel is an awesome host/owner. What up to Brooklyn egg creams.
author: avani a.

description: love you, guys!  coffee is so good and so much closer to my house than four barrel!
author: victoria s.

description: pretty good, had the latte, friendly service, gets crowded.
author: Brian R.

description: Visited Grand Coffee yesterday with my husband and kids.  We enjoyed the drinks and company.  We tried the limade, latte, brooklyn egg creme for the kids as well as owner recommended affogato for my husband.  All made very well.  The coffee is Four Barrel.  The owner is very friendly and is also knows his drinks.    The cafe is very clean and the design and detail are beautiful.  I look forward to visiting again and encourage everyone to check it out as well.
author: fadwa s.

description: The Carmel machidos put Starbucks and Peets to shame. Delicious. Check it out.
author: Bey A.

description: Favorite espresso], good pastries, uber friendly owner/worker.  Can't go wrong.
author: Paul B.
